attributes.title: Is Hasbro Seriously Overvalued? Should I Trim It Or Sell It?
summary: Hasbro is a two-bagger for me.
Should I sell it, trim it, or leave it alone?

attributes.content:
Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) has been one of my most successful dividend growth investments.

I purchased it in my Dividend Growth Portfolio on 9/7/2012 for $38.09. Its closing price Monday was $79.52, for a price gain of 108%. The position has grown to become 5% of my portfolio. The company's yield has fallen to 2.2% because of its price growth has outpaced its dividend growth.

My business plan has this guideline (not a hard-and-fast rule) for selling stocks: I will seriously consider selling if (among other things)

  • a stock "bubbles or becomes seriously overvalued"
  • its yield drops below 2.5%

Here is what Hasbro has done in price and yield since I bought it:

Hasbro's yield is obviously below 2.5%. Is it seriously overvalued? Let's find out by putting it through its valuation paces.

FASTGraphs Default Valuation

Step 1 is to consult FASTGraphs and see whether, at its default setting, Hasbro looks overvalued.

The FASTGraphs default "fair" P/E for this stock is 15, which is the default for most dividend growth stocks. As you can see, HAS is priced 61% above its fair value by this reckoning. I would say that is serious overvaluation.

FASTGraphs Average Valuation

Step 2 is to reset the above graph to use Hasbro's own average valuation as the fair value line rather than the default setting of 15.

This changes the picture, but not much. The stock's current price is still 43% over its fair value calculated using HAS's 18-year average P/E of 16.9 for fair valuation. I would say this still suggests serious overvaluation.

Morningstar

Step 3 is to look at Morningstar's star rating for the stock.

On Morningstar's NPV system, which takes a different approach from FASTGraphs, HAS rates 2 stars on a 5-star system. I consider that overvalued, but not seriously so.
